description.plain:
The Chicago born Wasalu Muhammad Jaco first tasted success when he featured on Kanye West’s hit “Touch the Sky”, a track that shortly preceded his real breakout, his 2006 debut album Lupe Fiasco’s Food & Liquor, and he never looked back. He has established himself as one of the greatest urban wordsmiths of all time, with Genius even dubbing him the ‘Proust of Rap’.

While he’s now regarded of one of the 21st Century’s Hip-Hop greats, he wasn’t always a fan of the genre, initially disliking it due to the prominence of vulgarity and misogyny within it. In his late teens, he aspired to make it as a lyricist. In his early twenty’s, he met Jay-Z, who helped him sign with Atlantic Records in 2005. The following year, he released his debut album (Lupe Fiasco’s Food & Liquor), which was met with acclaim from fans and critics alike, as did his sophomore effort, Lupe Fiasco’s The Cool.

The following eight years of his career saw far less output than many would’ve anticipated. This can be partly attributed to his struggles with Atlantic Records. The executives wanted him to sign a 360 deal; however, as he refused to do so they instead shelved his already completed 3rd album, Lasers, and wouldn’t promote him as they had previously. The overseers at the label also interfered with his music (as they had tried to do with his fan-favorite track “Dumb it Down”); subsequently effecting the quality and sound of his third and fourth albums.

However, when it came to his fifth album, Tetsuo & Youth, he made no compromises, despite them again refusing to release his album, wanting to record a radio-friendly single for marketability. He released a promotional single preceding the album, but he stuck to his guns and made the album he wanted to make — and we at Genius are so glad he did.

After leaving Atlantic, Lupe released his first full-length solo album, DROGAS WAVE, in late 2018. Although not meeting immediate success on the market due to a lack of marketing, the project was immediately met with love by both hardcore Lupe fans and objective lovers of lyricism and storytelling; seeing it as a return to form for Lupe after what many fans saw as a letdown in 2017’s DROGAS Light.

songs.full_title: Mural by Lupe Fiasco
songs.title: Mural

description.plain:
A Mural is any piece of artwork painted, or applied directly on a wall, ceiling or other large permanent surface. A distinguishing characteristic of mural painting is that the architectural elements of the given space are harmoniously incorporated into the picture.  Lupe figuratively paints a picture in this song with all of the imagery presented within the lyrics.  It is a fantasy much like an actual Mural but something he wishes he could see in real life.  Hence the name “Mural.”

Therefore, the song “Mural” draws parallels to an actual mural, given its size (or length of 8 minutes) and the permanent impact the song will have. Some say “a picture is worth thousand words”, so it’s no coincidence this song contains 1377 words.

This is not the first time Lupe has crafted a long all-lyric/no-hook track. Peace of Paper/Cup of Jayzus came out back in 2013 and features seven minutes of brilliant wordplay.

songs.full_title: Bitch Bad by Lupe Fiasco (Ft. Poo Bear)
songs.title: Bitch Bad

description.plain:
The second official single from Lupe Fiasco’s Food & Liquor II: The Great American Rap Album Pt. 1, Bitch Bad tackles the use of the notorious word, “bitch”, and its effects, especially on children. As Lu seemingly cosigns, it actually accurately depicts Sigmund Freud’s Madonna–whore complex.

Notice that the title itself is a play on words, as the phrase is usually “bad bitch”. Also note that the track, which is produced by The Audibles (D. Jordan & Jimmy Giannos), sounds the way many Hip-Hop songs that use the word “bitch” – mainly trap music – do, and that Lupe changes his flow to sound slightly simplistic and mainstream like many of these rappers. He’s dubbed it his Rod Serling Twilight Zone Flow, since “sometimes you just gotta talk to em.” The song features background vocals from MDMA a.k.a Poo Bear.

Listen to “Bitch Bad” here and buy it from iTunes.

http://soundcloud.com/atlanticrecords/lupe-fiasco-bitch-bad-explicit

songs.full_title: Words I Never Said by Lupe Fiasco (Ft. Skylar Grey)
songs.title: Words I Never Said
songs.title_with_featured: Words I Never Said (Ft. Skylar Grey)

description.plain:
Lasers’s second single is a political statement by Lupe, and it was seemingly inspired by the events of the 2011 Egyptian Revolution.

Addressing topics such as war and racism, Lupe heavily criticizes the US government and challenges the status quo. He also talks about people’s willingness to blindly follow their government, saying that he himself doesn’t want to be silent and later regret that he never said anything; he wants to stand up and speak up.

The song thematically is similar to “Hurt Me Soul” and features guest vocalist Skylar Grey for the hook. This is actually Lupe and Skylar’s second collab after both appearing on Fort Minor’s “Be Somebody” back when they were both relatively unknown, and Skylar was known as Holly Brook.

Lupe (in)famously performed a 30 minute version of this song at an event celebrating Obama’s 2013 inauguration and was thrown off stage.

Checkout the Genius “Words I Never Said” music video breakdown here.

songs.full_title: SLR 2 by Lupe Fiasco
songs.title: SLR 2

description.plain:
Lupe Fiasco’s fan-requested response to Kendrick Lamar’s challenge on the Big Sean’s Control track.

He initially said he wouldn’t do one because there would be “no fun in that”. However, after two rap battles, goofy wordplay and another song, Lupe finally gave his fans what they wanted.

Reactions are split from absolute respect to straight up anger. People call it genius and others call it wack. One thing is sure, however:
Lupe Fiasco once again shows that even if he’s barely trying, he is still a dangerous player in the game.

Featuring multiple flows, two different languages and one clear target, the return of Super Lupe Fiasco has made quite an impact.

Fun Fact: It took Lu just 2 hours to make this masterpiece!

songs.full_title: The Show Goes On by Lupe Fiasco
songs.title: The Show Goes On

description.plain:
Lupe fans, the moment you’ve been waiting for is here – Lupe’s first official single off of the long-delayed LASERS!

Lupe interpolates the popular Modest Mouse single “Float On” into the chorus, giving record execs the poppy hook they so desperately desire, but still maintains lyrical credibility

In the song, Lupe discusses his problems with Atlantic Records in releasing LASERS and giving back to the hip-hop heads

OFFICIAL MUSIC VIDEO:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Rmp6zIr5y4U

songs.full_title: Superstar by Lupe Fiasco (Ft. Matthew Santos)
songs.title: Superstar

description.plain:
In the first single off his second concept album The Cool, Lupe Fiasco delivers one of his most popular songs yet with a melancholic, lyrical meditation on the drawbacks of being in the limelight, alongside a memorable hook provided by Matthew Santos that allowed his rise to fame.

As the song’s music video reveals, however, “Superstar” also holds a second, less obvious meaning underneath the surface that ties into the strange story pertaining to The Cool’s Michael Young History.

His highest charting single

songs.full_title: Old School Love by Lupe Fiasco (Ft. Ed Sheeran)
songs.title: Old School Love

description.plain:
This song was thought to be the first official single for Lupe’s fifth studio LP Tetsuo & Youth, but it didn’t end up making the final cut.

Production-wise, the track features a piano melody reminiscent of Kanye West’s “Family Business.”

The song serves as direct advice to an unnamed, young, up coming hip hop artist (messages of staying true to one’s self, being humble and respectful flow throughout the verses).

Lu’s also created a blog here where you can share some of your own old school love.

songs.full_title: Adoration of the Magi by Lupe Fiasco (Ft. Crystal Torres)
songs.title: Adoration of the Magi
songs.title_with_featured: Adoration of the Magi (Ft. Crystal Torres)

description.plain:
The Adoration of the Magi is a name traditionally given to the artistic portrayals of Jesus Christ’s Nativity. Three Magi, often represented as kings or wise men, find Joseph & Mary, with Jesus laying in a manger by following the Star of Bethlehem.

Lupe timed the song’s release date of January 6th (Australian time), with The Epiphany – a Christian holiday celebrating the appearance of the infant Jesus to the Magi. The Magi are said to have offered him gifts of gold, frankincense, and myrrh (Matthew 2:11).

Fun fact: Adoration of the Magi is also the name of early paintings by Leonardo da Vinci and Sandro Botticelli. Tetsuo & Youth’s album art just happens to be a painting by Lupe, titled Uomo Mangiato Tigre (Man Eating Tiger).



This is also Lupe’s favourite song off T&Y:

https://twitter.com/LupeFiasco/status/552174168632877057

songs.full_title: Prisoner 1 & 2 by Lupe Fiasco (Ft. Ayesha Jaco)
songs.title: Prisoner 1 & 2

description.plain:
A culmination of two songs: Prisoner 1 and Prisoner 2, with 2 different hooks. Prisoner 1 &  2 touch on incarceration and racial profiling.

Lu stated that this song was made for his close friend, Chilly Chill. However he also stated that Prisoner 1&2 is one of the songs that has many pieces running at the same time. The way Chilly Chill is trapped in prison, is the same way Lu is trapped in the music industry, specifically his record deal.

The prisoners are prisoners in a modern day penitentiary, and also represent the prisoners crucified alongside Jesus (Luke 23:39-43).

Both parts follow a parallel to the Standord Prison Experiment, which examined how ordinary individuals became menaces to enforce the prison laws over prisoners. In addition, it points towards the failure of the prison system on both “prisoners” parts leading to perpetual states of malpractice and a failed solution to convinced criminals.

songs.full_title: Kick, Push by Lupe Fiasco
songs.title: Kick, Push

description.plain:
Lupe Fiasco’s debut single from his first album Food & Liquor tells the story of young boy and his love for skateboarding. The lyrics follow the skateboarder through many stages of his life such as his childhood, dating, marriage, and adulthood.

The song features lush, orchestral instrumentation from producer Soundtrakk.

In an August interview with Hard Knock TV, Lupe clears up rumors, letting it be known that this song is not about drug dealing:

I think on the surface, you know what the songs are about at the end of the day. I don’t think it’s like a big mystery. It’s not like a riddle… It may take a little bit more digging to kinda get what the song’s about, but in its totality, it’s not something that you need to be a rocket scientist to kinda figure out. It’s people who still think ‘Kick Push’ is about drug dealing. I had a dude tell me he thought ‘Kick Push’ was about basketball, so you know who knows what people think at the end of the day.

Lupe further clarifies this in his more recent track “Peace of Paper/Cup of Jayzus”.

description.plain:
A sprawling polemic about the pressures to simplify one’s lyrics to appeal to the mainstream – Lupe will have none of it.

It is a song Russian novel-esque in its depth, and rich with references: 3 different hooks, lengthy verses, one intro, and multiple outros.

This song, among others, is why we have dubbed Lupe the RapGenius™ King of Lyrical Trickiness

songs.full_title: Dots & Lines by Lupe Fiasco
songs.title: Dots & Lines

description.plain:
The cover art Lupe posted on Instagram is the insignia of the Bavarian Illuminati.
The owl on top of the book is the owl of Minerva, who symbolizes wisdom.

Lupe posted the cover art on his Instagram with the Latin caption Mille Annorum Lumen, which translates to mean “a thousand years old.”

http://instagram.com/p/xNGjycsKfD/?modal=true

The title Dots and Lines refers to the Pigpen cipher, a very basic cryptographic system that uses monoalphabetic substitution to replace characters with dots and lines. Freemasons began using the Pigpen cipher, subsequently called the Freemason’s cipher, in the early 18th century to keep their records of history and rites private, and for correspondence between lodge leaders.

The title refers to Lupe’s ability to communicate with certain listeners. The first Freemasons used the three dots to symbolize the past, the present and the future, but also the three degrees of the blue lodges (entered apprentice, fellowcraft and master).

songs.full_title: Daydreamin' by Lupe Fiasco (Ft. Jill Scott)
songs.title: Daydreamin’

description.plain:
On a cool summer’s day, Lupe Fiasco kicks back and dreams of skyscraper robots and stereotypical rap videos. The first verse was inspired by his father, an engineer, who told Lupe as a child that if you put all Chicago’s city buildings together they would form a giant robot. Lupe then uses satirical parody for the bulk of the second verse, which describes many of the stereotypes surrounding modern Hip Hop culture.

“Daydreamin'” won the 2008 Grammy for Best Urban/Alternative Performance. Interestingly, Lupe was sick with pneumonia on the day of the awards and couldn’t receive it in person. Rather, it was sent to his lawyer who had it for the next 9 years until Lupe and his Grammy were finally reunited on his way to a show in Cincinnati. Check out his long overdue Grammy acceptance speech below:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rz-3VQwwpDQ

songs.full_title: Hurt Me Soul by Lupe Fiasco
songs.title: Hurt Me Soul

description.plain:
Lupe discusses his conflicting feelings about rap; he feels torn liking a genre that glamorizes misogyny and materialism; such corrupt influences hurt “he” (Jamaican for “his”) soul

Similar thematic exploration is done on “Words I Never Said.”

Single off of Lupe Fiasco’s third album, Lasers – Jay-Z made it a hot line, Lupe made it a hot song.

songs.full_title: Deliver by Lupe Fiasco
songs.title: Deliver

description.plain:
“Deliver” is the first official single off Tetsuo & Youth. The cover art depicts a fictitious Frank’s Pizza delivery car stopped in front of an ominous-looking house. The straight line through the image is akin to the red circle-with-a-line-through-it “no” symbol.

On the surface, the song’s title & hook relate to certain pizza joints that won’t deliver to neighbourhoods that are considered high-risk. (Interestingly, this topic was the subject of a Twitter conversation with Lupe in August 2013).

However in true Lupe fashion, there’s another level to his lyrics taking the form of a social commentary on deliverance, or lack thereof, for people living in the ghetto.

https://twitter.com/LupeFiasco/status/544201798093770752

Not-so-fun fact: Just 3 days after this track was released a man was shot and killed while delivering a pizza in Chicago’s Northwest Side.



On Dec. 15th Lupe premiered the official video on World Star Hip Hop (watch and see if you can catch the reference to this famous painting by Michelangelo):
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=R40DFzvbMtE

songs.full_title: Strange Fruition by Lupe Fiasco (Ft. Casey Benjamin)
songs.title: Strange Fruition

description.plain:
Lupe treated a Marquette University Hip-Hop forum to an acapella piece for the second verse from this track. Yeah, its that exclusive. We getting Lupe verses 2 albums early out here son. That’s like driving a 2013 Maserati in 2009.

Originally planned to be the outro for the album.

You’ll notice that the verse is written in the form of a Shakespearean Sonnet.

Note the title’s reference to the anti-lynching song most famously sung by Billie Holiday, “Strange Fruit”

Strange Fruit was originally a poem written by Abel Meeropol that addressed the issues of racism, emphasizing the horrors of the lynching of African Americans. Similarly, Lupe’s “Strange Fruition” is also a song that address inequality and racism that still exists today.

songs.full_title: Peace of Paper/Cup of Jayzus by Lupe Fiasco
songs.title: Peace of Paper/Cup of Jayzus

description.plain:
Lu announced its release on August 3, then proceeded to tweet what seems to be the majority of its lyrics in segments through August 7th.



Screenshots for all the lyrics are available via the photos on his twitter feed – you can peep them all here.

This instrumental is VERY similar to Jay Z’s “Holy Grail,” the intro to his album Magna Carta…Holy Grail.

Also, the song’s title is a play on Jay Z’s album title. Peace of Paper is to Magna Carta as Cup of Jayzus is to Holy Grail. It’s okay if you didn’t get it before.
https://twitter.com/chancetherapper/statuses/377983921276723200

songs.full_title: They.Resurrect.Over.New. by Lupe Fiasco (Ft. Ab-Soul & Troi Irons)
songs.title: They.Resurrect.Over.New.

description.plain:
This is the first actual song when the album is played backwards, next “level” after this song is “Adoration of the Magi” which follows the video game theme.

Lupe brings in long time friend Ab-Soul, as well as L.A. singer Troi. The song’s title creates the acronym T.R.O.N. in reference to the 1982 coin-operated videogame Tron, 1982 also being the birth year of Lupe.



The title is also influenced by Pete Rock & CL Smooth’s “They Reminisce Over You (T.R.O.Y.)”, a song that has influenced Lupe in the past; check out the beat for “Around My Way”.

songs.full_title: Body of Work by Lupe Fiasco (Ft. Terrace Martin & Troi Irons)
songs.title: Body of Work
songs.title_with_featured: Body of Work (Ft. Terrace Martin & Troi Irons)

description.plain:
A “body of work” can be used to refer to the total output of a writer or artist. In this case it is referring to hip-hop, much like with Common’s “I Used to Love H.E.R.”

The song is about Lupe’s relationship with hip-hop as well as the “work” (another name for drugs) being smuggled within the body of hip-hop.

The lead character in the movie “Lucy” is captured and a bag of drugs is forcibly sewn into her abdomen to transport a drug.

(Closet full of bones) – “Lucy” is also the first Australopithecus afarensis skeleton.



On February 26, 2016 Lupe offered another hint about this track via Twitter:

https://twitter.com/lupefiasco/status/703466867302801408

songs.full_title: WAV Files by Lupe Fiasco
songs.title: WAV Files

description.plain:
In this sixth song off of DROGAS WAVE, Lupe speaks from the perspective of kidnapped Africans that jumped overboard slave ships during the middle passage. Lupe spins the narrative to as if the souls of the slaves are still alive, traveling back to their homeland in Africa. The song is a central part of the narrative of the “LongChains”. Lupe gave a brief summary of the LongChains on reddit, during the creation of DROGAS WAVE.

WAV Files are a computer file format for audio (music). This connects with how Lupe connects the present and the past throughout this song and the LongChains narrative. He uses the story to comment on his relationship with his former label Atlantic.

I could never be a slave, niggas
They gon' have to pay me, Navy
Downloaded by the tidals like JAY-Z

The name “WAV Files” can also refer to lines of slaves (“files”) jumping into the waves (“WAV”).

songs.full_title: The Cool by Lupe Fiasco
songs.title: The Cool

description.plain:
Taken from his debut album Food & Liquor, Lupe Fiasco spins a lyrical tale about a hustler who is shot to death but miraculously comes back to life.

This track became the basis for Lupe’s sophomore effort, Lupe Fiasco’s The Cool, a concept album about a young kid, Michael Young History, caught up in gang and drug life. Dubbed the “Coolest saga,” several songs from Lupe’s second album constitute the beginning of the story, while this track represents the end.

songs.full_title: Paris, Tokyo by Lupe Fiasco
songs.title: Paris, Tokyo

description.plain:
The sixth track on Lupe’s The Cool. Lupe explained the inspiration behind the song:

I love Paris, I love Tokyo… And what inspired me to write the song was that between ‘Food And Liquor’ and this album we travelled EVERYWHERE – multiple countries, multiple towns, multiple tours. So I just developed a knack and a love for touring, even if I didn’t want to do it! You know, despite the lyrical wear and tear it has on your body – particularly with the different climates – just by force I had to fall in love with it! And of course another side to it all is, when you travel, you leave people behind. So I actually wrote the song for my girl. Because I’d be gone so much we’d go for two months at a time without seeing each other. So it’s basically her song. Just to let her know that, wherever I go, she comes with me – even if it is just mentally or in spirit.

It was produced by Soundtrakk and samples the instrumental “San Juan Sunset” by Eumir Deodato.

Just to let her know that, wherever I go, she comes with me – even if it is just mentally or in spirit.

It was produced by Soundtrakk and samples the instrumental “San Juan Sunset” by Eumir Deodato.

songs.full_title: Audubon Ballroom by Lupe Fiasco
songs.title: Audubon Ballroom

description.plain:
The Audubon ballroom was a theatre and ballroom located on Broadway at 165th Street in the Washington Heights neighborhood of Upper Manhattan, north of Harlem in New York. It is best known as the site of Malcolm X’s assassination on February 21, 1965.

Malcolm X was an influential African-American Muslim minister and human rights activist. He is often referenced by rappers like 2Pac

(Fun Fact: This samples one of Game’s more popular hits: My Life; “Audubon Ballroom” has a higher tempo, but you can catch it best during the hook.
http://vimeo.com/69667098

songs.full_title: Unforgivable Youth by Lupe Fiasco (Ft. Jason Evigan)
songs.title: Unforgivable Youth

description.plain:
In this song, Lupe is describing the things
America has done in its history starting with the first verse being about how Columbus “discovered” “The New World”.

The Second verse is about the slavery that went on in the country and the belief of “Manifest Destiny” and spreading to the west.

The final verse takes place in the future, and scientist discover the way we used to lived in a society, thinking we are of high class with no problems and living in peace with everyone being equal, quoting the Constitution.  This all being ironic since none of that was true.

Things that I don't know
The icicles they grow
They never let me go
Scars are left as proof
But tears they soak on through
Things I've done
My young
My unforgivable youth

[Verse 1: Lupe Fiasco]
With land on the horizon and passion in their eyes and
What they think are islands are much more in their size and
Bountiful and plentiful and resource to provide them
Supplies slim, morale once so heavily inside them
Now steadily declining
Return is not an option as necessity denies them

Not the material things of kings that could never last forever
But secrets of the spirit world and how to live in harmony together
Unbeknownst to him his head would be the first that they would sever

From native caretakers who can barely understand

Warns, "One can not steal what was given as a gift;

By your future generations doomed to pay for your mistreatments

Things that I don't know

But tears they soak on through
Things I've done
My young

songs.full_title: Jump by Lupe Fiasco (Ft. Gizzle)
songs.title: Jump

description.plain:
https://twitter.com/LupeFiasco/status/818496554487185409

“Jump” debuted as the Beats 1 Radio world record on January 9th, 2017. This bass heavy cut, courtesy of longtime core producer Soundtrakk, features Lupe and Gizzle trading storytelling bars about an unusual meeting gone interstellar.

The song attempts to cast the relationship between gangsta rap and gangsterism through the lens of the relationship between a real gangsta (Gizzle as Suzie Uzi) and her ghostwriter (Lupe) as they set out to rise to the top of the rap game.

This song samples the vocals from the dance track “Bla Bla Bla” by Gigi D'Agostino.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=g6t8g6ka4W0

Had a long money minor, do that action for them figures
Her influence fully automatic, crackin' off the Richter, yeah!

[Verse 3: Gizzle]

Now where the bitches? Get them intergalactic asses to clappin'
Break down some of that candy and roll it up in a wrapper for a rapper
Nah, I could never go back to trappin'

With a lit match in your left hand and your right hand is a gas can
And at any given moment, I could burn this shit up
Why you standin' there just lookin', nigga? Turn that shit up
Hop in some of this alien pussy, let me know how it work

[Verse 4: Lupe Fiasco]

songs.full_title: Form Follows Function by Lupe Fiasco
songs.title: Form Follows Function

description.plain:
“Form follows function” was the slogan of the great Chicago School architect Louis Sullivan, whose masterpieces (Flatiron, Carson Pirie Scott) inaugurated the modernist style in architecture

Lupe murders this track filled with top notch imagery, using concepts like religion or drugs (only one mentioned was weed) as metaphors in the verses. This is where Lupe really flexes hard.

songs.full_title: Little Death by Lupe Fiasco (Ft. Nikki Jean)
songs.title: Little Death

description.plain:
According to Lu, this track “has so many pieces running at the same time.”

The three verses represent three different religious paradigms and they clash with politics.  The first verse deals with sex, the second with treatment of animals; specifically how they are to be slaughtered, and the third speaks on the justice system.

Each hook is told from the perspective of the devil. Varying by the verse it follows, the devil is trying to persuade a person to “raise hell” by acting immoral.

“La petite mort” is french for “little death,” which is the title of the track. “La petite mort” can refer to the spiritual release that comes with orgasm or to a short period of melancholy. It can also be used when some undesired thing has happened to a person and has affected them so much that “a part of them dies inside.”

The double meaning of “la petite mort, la petite mort” ties together the theme: Following the devil can give you immense pleasure at the time, but a small part of your soul dies every time you commit sin.

It is worth noting that Lupe previously collaborated with Nikki Jean on a song entitled “Little Weapon,” from Lupe’s second album The Cool, to which this song might be a sequel.

songs.full_title: Streets On Fire by Lupe Fiasco (Ft. Matthew Santos)
songs.title: Streets On Fire

description.plain:
Lupe Fiasco and Matthew Santos describe an apocalyptic world being swept under a massive, perhaps figurative plague of some sort. Though the “disease” can be interpreted plenty different ways, it’s most likely in allusion to depression, the HIV virus, street temptation, or government corruption.

The rough drum sample is sampled from “Amen, Brother” by The Winstons.

songs.full_title: Put You On Game by Lupe Fiasco
songs.title: Put You On Game

description.plain:
Interpretation No.1: The five greatest evils


This song introduces, according to Lupe, the five greatest evils known to man. He creatively personifies these evils by giving each of them a voice, making it seem as though they are all competing to see who is the worst.

• Money • Drugs • Capitalism  • Gangsters • Guns

Interpretation No.2: The devil inherent in every person


The title, “Put You On Game” and the recurring vocal, “Let me put you on game” is Lupe asking the listener (You) to allow him to explain the basics of ‘the game’. The purpose being that you will awaken from the system and assist humanity in overcoming its inherent susceptibility to evil.

Interpretation No.3: Corrupt world leaders or Illuminati


References to corrupt corporations are  weaved throughout this track; “Over priced medicine” and the ruler of , “The oval offices”. The Game is an extremely complicated and well-articulated system which was created by the planets corrupt rulers (Monarchies,Governments, global corporations etc). It is believed by many that these rulers of the world are the ones who are orchestrating things such as world domination at the cost of third world countries and brain washing of their own citizens via the media they control.



More information can be found in this Genius blog post.

songs.full_title: Blur My Hands by Lupe Fiasco (Ft. Guy Sebastian)
songs.title: Blur My Hands

description.plain:
“Blur My Hands” is the third track on Lupe Fiasco’s Tetsuo and Youth. The song features Guy Sebastian — who also collaborated with Lupe on “Battle Scars”.

Lupe released 2 unofficial versions of the song’s cover art. The first (shown below) features Marathon of Hope runner Terry Fox — to whom Lupe references in the third verse.

The second shows an iconic photo of Johnny Cash giving the finger — an image that supports the theme described throughout the song’s hook.

songs.full_title: Madonna (And Other Mothers in the Hood) by Lupe Fiasco (Ft. Nikki Jean)
songs.title: Madonna (And Other Mothers in the Hood)
songs.title_with_featured: Madonna (And Other Mothers in the Hood) (Ft. Nikki Jean)

description.plain:
“Madonna” is derived from the Italian term “ma donna,” meaning “my lady.” Lupe draws parallels between the Virgin Mary, and mothers raising children in ghetto neighborhoods. They fear their children will become victims of city violence, just as Mary feared Jesus' persecution. The imagery of a mother holding her deceased son at the end of the song mirrors that of Mary at Jesus' crucifixion.

Lupe’s fixation with The Bible on T&Y, as well as visual art, explains why he substituted the English word Mary in favor of Madonna. It’s also worth noting that the three songs all appear back-to-back on the albums tracklist, and that Lupe rearranged the titles to tweet:

https://twitter.com/lupefiasco/status/550728084094062592

We can thank Lupe’s longtime friend Bishop G for this song. You can also check out the music video here.

songs.full_title: Next To It by Lupe Fiasco (Ft. Ty Dolla $ign)
songs.title: Next To It

description.plain:
“Next To It” was the second promotional single of his fifth studio album, Tetsuo & Youth, being “Mission” the first.

The track features singing and production by Ty Dolla $ign, who in an interview with Complex, praised Lupe speaking about their single:

“He’s definitely in my Top 10 now. I don’t know why I wasn’t paying attention but after I did that song with him. I’ve done songs with a lot of people right? This nigga right here, me and Shafiq did the beat, he gave me an idea for the hook, I went in and did the hook, and then he went in the booth and just spit the whole fucking song, dog. I promise you it was off the top of the head, no written. The whole song. Probably went back and changed like two fuck-ups. I’ve never seen that done before. Lupe is that guy.”

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9gRPsz7Gf5k

songs.full_title: Beautiful Lasers (2 Ways) by Lupe Fiasco (Ft. Poo Bear)
songs.title: Beautiful Lasers (2 Ways)

description.plain:
This song is the 7th track off of Lupe’s long awaited album LASERS. The song is about Lupe’s once suicidal thoughts which he alludes to in a recent interview in the February 2011 issue of “Loud & Quiet” magazine

He talks about the option of which path to take, the correct path through the door or the other way out.

songs.full_title: Haile Selassie by Lupe Fiasco (Ft. Nikki Jean)
songs.title: Haile Selassie

description.plain:
Haile Selassie was a Ethiopian regent for 14 years, and an Emperor for 44 years later.  Haile was a decorated politician who’s ideals  lead Ethiopia to being a charting member of the United Nations. Selassie suppressed many rebellions, he was viewed by many to be a messiah, a God-reincarnate walking on Earth. Despite this he was criticized by many human rights activists.

This song was released in 2014 on the mixtape, Lost in the Atlantic.

songs.full_title: Failure by Lupe Fiasco
songs.title: Failure

description.plain:
Exemplary lyricism from the Fahrenheit 1st & 15th mixtape. The title of the song is a play on the meaning of Lupe’s stage name “Fiasco”, meaning “failure” in Latin

Rap Genius thinks Lu is being too modest about himself here, though, since it took us forever to explain this one!
